Headline.Para: The Equine and Political Meanings of 'Feeling One's Oats'; A phrase recently used to describe President Trump recalls the days when horses were crucial to society

LeadPara.Para: As President Donald Trump's behavior has seemed more confident and unrestrained lately, commentators have frequently been using an equine metaphor to describe his actions: Mr. Trump, it appears, is "feeling his oats."

On New York Magazine's Daily Intelligencer blog, for instance, Heather Hurlburt wondered if the firing of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson was due to "Donald Trump feeling his oats and indulging an impulse he'd been suppressing for months."

TailParas.Para: Jeffrey C. Billman of Indy Week wrote that "now he's a chaos president who seems to be feeling his oats, at least enough to elbow out dissenting voices." And the same phrase has been applied to Mr. Trump recently by MSNBC host Chris Hayes, CNN political analyst Brian Karem and National Review senior editor Jonah Goldberg.

"Feeling one's oats," when applied to humans, typically describes someone who feels newly emboldened, often behaving in a cocky or arrogant fashion. But as the "oats" part of the idiom suggests, the description was originally applied to horses and how they act after they are fully fed.

The expression dates back to the early 19th century, used for the frisky, energetic movements of a horse when it has a belly full of oats. The earliest example recorded by the Oxford English Dictionary comes from the Boston Transcript in 1831: "Whether the pony felt his oats...he took a frightful canter."

The expression quickly got transferred to people, appearing in 1843 in the writing of the Canadian humorist Thomas Chandler Haliburton. Sam Slick, Haliburton's straight-talking Nova Scotian protagonist, tells another character, "You know that, and feel your oats, too, as well as any one. So don't be so infarnal mealy-mouthed, with your mock modesty."

Herman Melville made a more explicit connection between lively horses and humans in his famous 1853 short story "Bartleby the Scrivener." The protagonist, a Manhattan lawyer, tells of giving a fine coat to one of his scriveners named Turkey, which seemed to make him more insolent: "In fact, precisely as a rash, restive horse is said to feel his oats, so Turkey felt his coat."

Mr. Trump isn't the first president to be described this way. After Barack Obama delivered his State of the Union speech in 2013 at the start of his second term, Don Baer, CEO of public-relations and communications firm Burson-Marsteller and a onetime senior adviser to Bill Clinton, observed, "I think the president is feeling his oats as a result of his re-election."

Used today, "feeling one's oats" sounds like a bit of a throwback to a more agrarian age. It's not the only oats-related idiom still lingering in the language: "Sowing one's wild oats" goes back to the idea that uncultivated oats are useless as a crop, and therefore sowing them is a frivolous activity. Being "off one's oats" means lacking appetite, like a horse that doesn't want to feed.

We have retained many other horsy turns of phrase long after horse-riding has faded as a means of transportation. Think of giving someone "free rein," originally referring to loosening the reins on a horse to let it move more freely.
To complete the metaphor, one might say that Mr. Trump is giving free rein to his impulses these days, now that he is unbridled and no longer champing at the bit.
